results.title: To Sir, with love
results.brief_description: A novice teacher faces a class of rowdy, undisciplined, working-class punks in this classic film that reflected some of the problems and fears of teens in the sixties. Sidney Poitier gives one of his first performances as Thackeray, an unemployed engineer who turns to teaching in London’s tough East End. The graduating class, led by Denham (Christian Roberts), Pamela (Judy Geeson), and Barbara (Lulu who also sings the hit title song), sets out to destroy Thackeray as they did his predecessor by breaking his spirit. But Thackeray meets the challenge by treating the students as young adults who will soon enter a world where they must stand or fall on their own. When offered an engineering job, Thackeray must decide whether he wants to stay. From the novel by E. R. Braithwaite.

results.title: To Kill a mockingbird [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Pakula-Mulligan Productions, Brentwood, Alan Pakula and Robert Mulligan
results.brief_description: This is an atmospheric adaptation by Horton Foote of Harper Lee’s sensitive novel of the same name. Told in retrospect, it successfully tackles the themes of racial prejudice in America’s Deep South with the gradual maturing of compassion and social insight in children. Gregory Peck plays Atticus Finch, the soft spoken, small town, Alabama lawyer given the responsibility of defending Tom Robinson, a black man unjustly accused of rape. This is perfectly balanced with Finch as the family man who has the added responsibility of bringing up two motherless and inquisitive children, played by Mary Badham and Phillip Afford. (Awards: Winner of three Academy Awards, including Best Actor for Gregory Peck)

results.title: To have and have not
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Jack L. Warner and Howard Hawks
results.brief_description: Lauren Bacall’s sizzling screen debut in “To have and have not” also marked her first role opposite Humphrey Bogart. The film that brought this legendary couple together is an adaptation of the Ernest Hemingway novel, set on the German controlled island of Martinique during World War II. The compelling script by Jules Furthman and William Faulkner captures the drama of the war-torn 40’s and is peppered with witticisms and wisecracks. Supporting players Walter Brennan and Hoagy Carmichael keep the action brisk, but the scenes between sullen Bogie and silky Bacall exude a heat and humour that pervade the entire picture.

results.title: To Catch a thief
results.brief_description: The French Riviera serves as the picturesque backdrop for this classic, suspenseful Hitchcock caper with Cary Grant as John Robie, a reformed cat burglar once known as “The Cat”, suspected in a new wave of jewel thefts from luxury hotels. Meeting pampered heiress Frances (Grace Kelly at her most ravishing), he sees the chance to bait the mysterious thief with her mothers’ (Jessie Royce Landis) fabulous jewels and clear himself of suspicion. His plan backfires, but Frances, who believes him guilty, proves her love by helping him escape and in a spine-tingling climax, the real criminal is exposed. Script including the much-imitated fireworks scene by John Michael Hayes. The cinematography by Robert Burks won the Oscar for Best Cinematography, 1954. Co-starring John Williams, Charles Vanel, Brigitte Auber, Jean Martinelli and Georgette Anys. Based on the novel by David Dodge.

results.title: To Be or Not to Be
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Alexander Korda and Ernst Lubitsch
results.brief_description: A Warsaw theatre group, before and during the Nazi invasion, wages war on Hitler on a devious new battleground - the Shakespearean stage. The actors improvise an underground plot and an impersonation of invading Nazis, including Adolf Hitler. Stars Jack Benny, Robert Stack and Carole Lombard in her final performance.

results.title: Titanic
results.creator_credit: Lightstorm Entertainment, James Cameron and Jon Landau
results.brief_description: This sweeping love story sailed into the hearts of moviegoers around the globe, ultimately emerging as the most popular motion picture of all time. Starring Leonardo Di Caprio and Kate Winslet as star-crossed lovers who find themselves on the maiden voyage of the “unsinkable” R.M.S. Titanic. When the doomed luxury liner strikes an iceberg in the frigid North Atlantic, their passionate love affair becomes a thrilling race for survival. Winner of eleven Academy Awards including Best Picture, this tale of forbidden love and courage in the face of disaster triumphs as a true cinematic masterpiece. Presented in Widescreen format.

results.title: Tin men
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Mark Johnson and Barry Levinson
results.brief_description: A tale of two hustlers in competition with each other, one a smooth-talking ladies’ man, the other a loser surrounded by debt and emotional problems. Set in 1960s Baltimore, BB Bakowsky (Richard Dreyfus) and Ernest Tilley (Danny De Vito) are rival aluminium siding salesmen brought together through an unfortunate car accident. Each blames the other and a full-on feud ensues. Revenge becomes a game and BB succeeds in making life even more complicated when in order to infuriate Tilley, he attempts to sleep with Tilley’s wife, Nora (Barbara Hershey) only to end up falling in love with her. Although the dialogue is fast and furious with many hilarious scenes there is sense of a darker sadder story underneath. Cast includes John Mahoney, Seymour Cassel, Jackie Gayle.

results.title: Time regained [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Gemini Films, France 2 Cinema, Les Films du Lendemain, Paolo Branco and Raul Ruiz
results.brief_description: Confined to bed in his small apartment, Marcel Proust, is looking through old photos. As faded pictures jog his memory, real characters of his past intermingle with fictional ones from his novels. Proust’s world is like an interconnected gossip column penned by a rich intellectual snob with a refined sense of the comic, for whom music, painting, and literature in particular matter far more than society. The lost paradise of his childhood gives way to literary salons in Paris. To evoke the vast human comedy that surrounded and supported Proust, director Raul Ruiz blends the Baroque and the Surreal, creating a story like a series of corridors leading to the images, themes and stories which coursed through Proust’s novels. ‘Time Regained’ can be at times disconcerting for those not familar with Proust’s work, as Ruiz chose to have characters glide in and out of the story without formal introduction. In the spreading twilight, the shape of post-war society looms on the horizon. Proust died in 1922, but by the end of WWI most of his world had already vanished. Stars Catherine Deneuve, Vincent Perez, Emmanuelle Beart, John Malkovitch. Adapted from ‘Remembrance Of Things Past’ by Marcel Proust. In French with English subtitles. Reference: Ron Holloway. ‘Time Regained’. Cannes Internatinal Film Festival. Online. http://www.filmfestivals.com/cannes99/html/seloff11.htm
